koss@... wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger writes:
> 
>  > �ffffd2�fffffc�ffffce�ffffb0�ffffc3�fffffa wrote:
>  >
>  >> I want to test a package.  If I extends my own class,
>  >> it will save me lots of time.  :)
>  >
>  > This is interesting. I have never wanted my test class to extend a
>  > production code class.
> 
> I do it infrequently to try to get legacy code under test.

True enough. I consider it an advanced technique, and generally 
recommend it only for Competent (Dreyfus model) JUnit practitioners.

>  > More strongly, test code should be a client of
>  > production code, and not the other way around.
> 
> When I extend a class, am I not a client of that class?

Hmmm. Maybe "client" was the wrong word. I'm not used to saying "client" 
in that case, but it appears to be true. Let me try again:

Test objects should /use/ production objects, and not /be/ production 
objects.

>  > Why would this save you time?
> 
> His motivation isn't at all clear.

Indeed.
